last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27900995
My flatmate is autistic and he's easily the most 'normal' person in the flat. He's easily one of the most 'normal' people I know (including my wide range of very normie friends), and one of the easiest to relate/talk to, because he's had enough therapy and support to help him work through the autism until he can relate to the average person.

Autism is a spectrum. Some are literal retards who can't handle wearing the wrong-colour shoes on a Wednesday. Others are more subtle, and often have enough support and therapy to help them overcome their subtle quirks until they seem more more 'normal' than neurotypical people. Neurotypical people often do weird shit, knowing they won't be judged for it. Autistic people sometimes become so good at managing their own weird shit and fitting in, that they seem more normal than the normies.

As you get to know this guy, you'll likely notice a few odd quirks. But it sounds like he's really fucking good at managing his autism. You don't really have to treat him any different. He'll likely tell you outright if he's struggling with anything you say/do. If you're not sure, it's ok to just ask him outright. He'll probably appreciate the thoughtfulness.

last_replies.com:

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I'm sorry. That shit's fucking rough.

Are you sure it's gonna hurt, or is that the fear/anxiety talking?

>involves getting raped again
That's... not a good way to think of it. It might be a good idea to have someone you trust in the room with you, to hold your hand and calm you down. Or maybe talk to your doctor and let them know that you are terrified of the procedure, and ask them to be very slow, and work with you. Speak to them in advance and ask them to stop when you ask them to.
It's your body. You can decide what happens to it. And that includes saying 'no' to medical procedures.
Do get the ultrasound. You need it. But also, prepare yourself for it, mentally. And ask for as much support as you need. Do whatever it takes to make yourself comfortable.
If you can't go through with it, that's ok. You can always try again another time, when you feel more capable of it.

Are you in therapy?
Are you on medication?

A friend of mine was raped fairly recently (it must have happened sometime in the last few years), and she's got PTSD, too. Prior to being diagnosed with PTSD, she was initially given medication for depression, which exacerbated her panic attacks because it suppressed her emotions (VERY bad for PTSD sufferers because it prevents them from being able to process what happened to them in a healthy way).
If you're on medication that stops you from feeling things, you may need to talk to a psychiatrist about changing your medication. It's a shitty process, but it's necessary.

I suggest you contact the hospital/your doctor and ask for extensive information about the procedure. Ask what happens during the procedure, and why it's necessary. Ask if you can do X,Y,or Z to make yourself more comfortable. Arm yourself with knowledge. Sometimes fear of what 'could' happen is scarier than knowing what is actually gonna happen.

You can do it.

I've been together with my girlfriend for three and a half years at this point. We live on opposite sides of the earth and started dating when I was there on a trip. We've spent about 10 months of the relationship physically together. We started dating when we were both still in high school and I was obsessed with the idea of moving to her country in the future which is why I was vacationing there. Our relationship is very strong and trusting and I do love her with all my heart. In some respects she feels like family to me as she's been here multiple times and been introduced to my family. They even jokingly ask when it is we're getting married.
This is all something I've been fine with these few years and I have never as much as had the thought of being with someone else but recently I've been having doubts after having been introduced to this woman I get along with very well by my a family member. Ever since I've gotten to know her doubts have started to pile up and I keep imagining how much easier life would be if she was my girlfriend.
My girlfriend would actually be able to speak to my family and friends, she's comes from a family very similar to ours and has the same kind of humour meaning everyone would love her, she's just as driven to do stuff and try out new things as me, she's from the same country as me meaning I don't need to worry about my children growing up in between to cultures, her life goals are very compatible with mine, I wouldn't have to move to the other side of the world, we have many common interests and she's very attractive.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27901000
Cont.
I just started a 5 year university degree meaning me and my current girlfriend won't be together for at least another 6 or 7 years and I can't stop thinking about wanting to break it off even if things might not work out with this new girl. The only thing making me doubt myself is how much I'd hurt my girlfriend in the process of doing it. I do still love her but I'm not sure if I can handle it anymore at this point. Is this enough of a reason to break up? And is it selfish to think there'll be a good way to break it off to soften the impact on my girlfriend? We were both each others firsts and have talked about our future making me feel as if I'm destroying her plans.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27901003
It's a tough choice, OP.
Honestly, I think these are perfectly valid reasons to break up with your girlfriend. You might genuinely love her with all your heart, but there are practical hurdles that you need to overcome... and that's not necessarily gonna be possible.

If I were you, I'd make a point of talking to the gf about this (not about the other woman, but about your worries). Try to talk about your future and work out what it will realistically look like, whether you are both ok with making the necessary sacrifices to keep the relationship going, and what steps you can take to make it more bearable.
You obviously aren't happy to wait for her for 6-7 years while studying, for example. But she might be happy to study or work in YOUR country during that time period, so you can be together. She might not be happy to be away from her family for Christmas, but you might happily compromise by visiting her family for Christmas every year. See what kind of compromises you can make, and try to find a sustainable future for the relationship.

It sounds like you guys are serious about each other - a 3.5 year long LONG-TERM relationship is quite the fucking achievement. I think you have a good chance of making this work.

And if all else fails, I'm sorry, man. This shit happens, sometimes. Try to move on as best you can.

>>27901137

sub: I don't get along with anyone
com:
I know I'm probably the problem but I seriously cannot get along/connect to 95% of people. I can talk to people, sure. I can find new "friends", yes. I can pretend this and that but in reality I can't stand them. I hate talking to them, it's annoying, boring and a waste.

I find myself not giving a shit most times about anything they have to say. I don't care about video games, I don't care about the world cup, and I don't give a shit about gossiping. One of my friends likes to talk politics, another complains a lot about how difficult school is: so the topics are sometimes diverse, but I still just don't care. I pretend to, I act like I seriously give a shit but I honestly don't. I don't know why but I just can't. I find myself apathetic to everything.

I'm sure they feel differently though, there's at least some of them that believe that we have this real deep connection. But to me, it's never been anything but shallow. The moment a friend leaves me, for whatever reason, I find myself feeling indifferent. I basically forget about you. It probably doesn't help that I've had to leave friends multiple times in my life since I moved a lot as a kid but regardless I don't think I've ever had a real connection with someone.

It doesn't help either that most people are trying to fulfil an agenda, whether they know it or not. For example, someone might only talk to you because you're doing well in a class and are looking to get help. Or in general, they might talk to you because you have something they want.

I'm in my third year of university now, I have a few "friends/acquaintances" but I am an imposter. I don't give a shit about these people. I rather do work or something of value. At this point I probably won't ever date or find someone I can truly care about.

What do I do? I know its something to do with my mindset or personality. How do I go about fixing it? Do I fake it till I make it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
It's normal to be jealous over shit like that.
Imagine if your girlfriend's password was her male best friend's birthday. Imagine if he were hot. You'd probably feel insecure, too.

But it's not ok to treat your partner with such disrespect and mistrust, over something so small and unimportant. You aren't cheating on her. You're just honouring someone you care about.

Talk to your girlfriend. Try to soothe her jealousy/insecurity. Let her know that your password would be your best friend's birthday, even if she had a cock - you're just honouring a friend. Talk to her about it and let her know that you understand why she's feeling jealous over it, and assure her that there's nothing to worry about. Then let her know that her mistrust of you is hurtful and incredibly fucking unfair, so chill tf out.

When trying to calm her down, don't fall for any bullsht. Don't let her come between you and your friend. If she's jealous, that's ok. But it's not ok for her to try controlling your behaviour or treat you (or your friend) poorly as a result of her jealousy. She can't make you change your phone password. She can't stop you from hanging out with your friend. She can't shit-talk you or your friend over dumb shit, out of jealousy. If she pulls that kind of shit, defend yourself, defend your friend, and shut her shit down asap. You don't need to be mean or aggressive. But do be very fucking assertive and let her know that it's not ok.

Be cool about it. Be understanding. Be loving. But don't be a doormat.

So a friend of mine seems to be stuck in a really unhealthy rut. I’ll rattle off all their negative unhealthy habits, of which are compounding themselves into being incredibly depressed so you guys can have a gauge of it.

- has no job, was fired from the last one for stealing products (petty)

I’m trying to get them motivated to work again, they’re a bit of a digital artist so in that field as entry level, or trying to get them to resume university again. However it seems like they’re actively avoiding it & avoiding the people that want them to overall be better or healthier. I spoke with one of my best friends about it & he was saying it may not be worthwhile even bothering if they can’t even display an attempt towards improving their situation & are content with being in a depression spiral. Any thoughts on how to proceed?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27898175
Help them find a remote job so they can be a hermit for a while if that's what they want to do.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27898175
Yeah seems that their mental health is pretty bad. People who are in a depressive spiral don't do it because theyre "content" though, it's most likely (if not definitely) that this behavior is brought on due to his conditions. it's so easy to condemn and criticize others when you don't understand their experiences or what its like for them. Im assuming you nor your friend are psychologists, nor that you've personally experienced something similar since you're asking here.

Just accept that you don't know and be supportive. Clearly he's going through a rough time. It's true that sometimes people aren't going to take the help you offer, and at the end of the day you can't force them to. It's tough but unfortunately we can't always magically fix the issues the people we care about are going through. Its a battle.

Let him know that you're worried about him and that you're there for him as a friend if he ever needs it. I'd also probably recommend for him to consider visiting a therapist or psychologist if he's been struggling with mental health. Ask him how he is from time to time. Just show him that you care.

Hope your friend does better in the future

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27898175
I had a friend like that in my last year of high school. We're still close, I just don't put in the effort to make her improve herself anymore. You can't force people, especially mentally ill people, to get better. It doesn't work that way. I think the best you can do is be supportive without enabling them. You don't need to sit down with them and apply for jobs, but by encouraging them to leave the house and do things with you (if you find events and activities based on things they like, they're more likely to agree to come), or by talking about how much you enjoy your presumably better social and financial life, it might help wake them up to how sad their life is. I think they are likely very unhappy deep down with how their life is going, but I think that if you only make them feel awful and ashamed whenever you two hang out, they might not want to spend any time with you at all.

I completely understand the feeling of powerlessness as you watch someone you care about living a completely miserable life, but unfortunately for the most part it's out of your control. They need to want to get a job and improve their life for themselves.

name: Anonymous
com:
Looking for any tips from people with ADHD. I'm not diagnosed, but I think it's very likely that I have ADHD. Since my teenage days I always thought that I was depressed because I felt something "wrong" about me, but these last few years I was able to afford therapy, but to me surprise, both attempts I failed to qualify as depressed. They tested me and while I show some signs of mild depression, I'm not depressed. I couldn't afford more time in therapy so I just tried to go on, but things didn't work out for me, I still struggled to finish things, even small ones and I was constantly switching form being super motivated to feeling with no motivation at all.
I'm 26 now and I have failed at pretty much everything I've tried because I wasn't persistant enough and I just wne to the next thing I wanted to try. College dropout, failed artist, dumped by gf that still loved me, unable to keep jobs, etc. No matter how much of a mess I was in, I was never able to commit to make significant improvements in my life, even if for certain periods I was super motivated.
At that point I've already droped the idea of having some disorder and I thought I was just lazy (which is true) but then I saw this image and realized how much it fits to me situation. I never considered ADHD because while I always had problems to focus in my tasks, I was always calm and chill, but after reading more in depth I get that's not as simple as that, and that the whole thing really fits not only for my current situation, but also to my chilhood and teenage days. Hi anon, I have lots of experience with this, my own brother gave up on his dreams bc he couldn't pass Calc 1. I successfully passed Calc 1 with a 91% at a prestigious university, and accelerated pace - a summer 4 months instead of the normal 8 months during the regular year.

General rule of thumb, when doing homework, is - if you're stuck on a problem longer than 15 minutes, seek help - either ask a TA, use question-solver apps like Symbolab, or e-mail your prof/ask friends
When I took Calc 1 it was kind of an IQ test - they would deliberately choose the hardest forms of the concepts we were taught. Which was kind of exciting to be honest, I rose up to the challenge.

If you have to, drop other courses you're taking and do calc. Become obsessed with it if that's what it takes. If you can do every problem in the textbook you'll have no problem on tests or exams

>>27900451
haha

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27900636
oh one more thing. With calc, sometimes there are multiple correct ways to write out a solution (e.g. trig identities, ln's, logs, etc). So I raised my test scores by simply pointing out to my prof that I did all the calculations correctly and my answer was still correct, I just solved it in a way she didn't expect.
So go through all your graded tests and assignments to see where (and even IF you actually) you screwed up

Yeah one thing your reply reminded me of: calc will usually take more time than the rest of your classes put together. That's just how it is, the amount of repeated work required to learn all the little formulas and tricks is just unavoidable.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

Engineering outside of college will barely use any of the stuff you're learning now. Take comfort in that. The most important skill to develop during this time on your journey is the ability to learn. So you got a great opportunity here.

I graduate as an ME last year. When I struggled in calc, I would go to office hours or TA help sessions with specific questions on problems I was stuck on, this was a huge key. When you study, remember knowing 30 problems really well will go a lot further than doing 100 unique ones poorly.

To flex on you, I graduated with a 3.94 and I can tell you I considered Calc I as one of my hardest classes I had to take. It is a weed out class at most Universities.

name: Anonymous
com: What does one do at the therapist? Do you just lie on a couch and tell life stories and about your problems as he quietly makes notes nodding with his head, then says something fancy and you try it out then go back to him to tell him how it worked out?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27899176
First consultation, you are supposed to give a general idea of what you are looking for and then they tell you whether it’s within their expertise. If you’re just having general life issues they’ll usually say they can help, but if you want something specific like EMDR or you’re specifically looking for a childhood trauma therapist, they might tell you they have a different area of expertise and send you to someone else. Assuming you do decide to start seeing them, you’ll then have your first session. During the first session you will start giving them your mental “medical history” - your life story, how you grew up, what’s happening now, whether you take any medications or drugs, who are the people in your support network, etc. By the third session they start doing what they set out to do, which depends on the type of therapy you’re doing. What you described sounds like psychodynamic therapy, which will involve them asking questions about your life and coaxing you towards various insights based on your answers. Some methods, like CBT, will also involve them giving you “homework” in which you have to behave a certain way, do journaling, say affirmations, do breathing techniques, etc. Regardless of the type of therapy you’re doing, you will usually begin each subsequent session with an update on your progress, which usually involves a questionnaire about how you’re feeling and behaving. At some point during the process, you may be diagnosed with something - or you may just have general life issues rather than a mental illness. It’s a good idea to ask your therapist what they are diagnosing you with because not everyone will tell you right away and also because it can affect your insurance coverage. Also, at some point, especially if you’re not improving, they may suggest medication. You will need to be referred to a psychiatrist to get the medication if your therapist is not certified to prescribe it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27900211
Continued
You do not have to accept the medication. The only way they can force you to take it (at least in the US) is if they have reason to believe you’re an immediate danger to yourself or others, in which case they can hospitalize you and can only force you to take medication during the hospital stay. If you are going to discuss suicidal or violent thoughts and do not wish to be hospitalized, you should say that you have a plan in place in case you feel like really doing it, such as, “If I really feeling like killing myself, I will call the suicide hotline.” Then they can’t hospitalize.
